Title: Fry Bread: A Native American Family Story
Author: Maillard, Kevin Noble
Subject: Family and tradition
Synopsis: This portrayal of a modern Native American family, told in lively and powerful verse, uses fry bread as a metaphor for love, sharing, and honoring the old while embracing the new.
Awards: School Library Journal Starred, October 2019; Booklist starred, October, 2019; Pub Weekly, August 2019; Kirkus starred, July 2019; New York Times, November 2019; Horn Book, November 2019; Robert F. Sibert Informational Book Award Medal 2020

Title: Our Class is a Family
Author: Olsen, Shannon
Subject: Class Community
Synopsis: Help build a sense of community within classrooms, help students feel safe, included, and loved.

Title: Hidden Figures
Author: Shetterly, Margot Lee
Subject: Women in STEAM
Synopsis: Based on a true story of four black women who helped NASA launch men into space

Title: The Bad Seed
Author: John, Jory
Subject: SEL
Synopsis: A naughty seed with a bad attitude, bad temper, and bad manners vows to change his life for the better, but his efforts are met with skepticism by his friends.

Title: Divorce is the Worst
Author: Higginbotham, Anastasia
Subject: Divorce
Synopsis: Part of the Ordinary Terrible Things series, Divorce Is the Worst is a funny but frank picture book for kids whose parents are going through a divorce. In her iconic straightforward-but-sensitive way, author Anastasia Higginbotham sheds light on how hard it is for children to stay whole when their whole world, and the people in it, split apart.

Title: Taco Falls Apart
Author: Miles, Brenda
Subject: SEL
Synopsis: Taco Falls Apart gets kids thinking about how their thoughts shape feelings and behavior. Friendly and funny, this evidence-based science-informed book skillfully presents a fundamental concept of cognitive-behavior psychology in a way kids can understand -- how the interplay between thoughts, feelings, and behavior shape who we are and how we experience everything.

Title: Two New Years
Author: Ho, Richard
Subject: Multicultural representation (Chinese and Jewish)
Synopsis: "For this multicultural family, inspired by the author's own, two New Years mean twice as much to celebrate! In the fall, Rosh Hashanah, the Jewish New Year, offers an opportunity to bake challah, dip apples in honey, and lift voices in song. In the spring, Lunar New Year brings a chance to eat dumplings, watch dragon dances, and release glowing lanterns that light up the sky

Title: The Truth About Dragons
Author: Leung, Julie
Subject: Multicultural representation (Eastern and Western mythologies)
Synopsis: In a mix of Eastern and Western mythologies, a mother tells her child about two forests inhabited by different, but equally enchanting dragons that coexist within the child's heart.
Awards:
Kirkus Reviews
School Library Journal Starred

Title: The Bright Side
Author: Otis, Chad
Subject: Home Insecurity, SEL
Synopsis: "When an unhoused boy enters school, he runs afoul of rules and finds himself alone, but finds that he has imagination, resilience, and can define 'the bright side' for himself"
Awards:
Kirkus Reviews starred
SLJ express starred

Title: We Belong to the Drum
Author: Lamouche, Sandra
Subject: Indigenous representation
Synopsis: "Starting daycare, Nikosis, who grew up going to powwows with his family, where he was immersed in music, dance and the sound of the drum, feels like he doesn't fit in, until his mother and teachers use the drums to help him find connection and comfort"

Title: Dreamers
Author: Morales, Yuyi
Subject: Immigration, Hispanic representation
Synopsis: "An illustrated picture book autobiography in which award-winning author Yuyi Morales tells her own immigration story"--Provided by publisher.
Awards:
Booklist starred
Horn Book Guide starred
Kirkus starred

Title: Something Happened in Our Town: a child’s story about racial injustice
Author: Celano, Marianne
Subject: Racial injustice, civil rights
Synopsis: "American Psychological Association." After discussing the police shooting of a local Black man with their families, Emma and Josh know how to treat a new student who looks and speaks differently than his classmates.

Title: Just ask! Be Different, Be Brave, Be You!
Author: Sotomayor, Sonia
Subject: Building a sense of community
Synopsis: A story where friends with different abilities work together to build a community garden.

Title: I Am Enough
Author: Byers, Grace
Subject: self-acceptance
Synopsis: A story about loving who you are and being kind to one another.

Title: Geraldine
Author: Lilly, Elizabeth
Subject: Friendship and moving
Synopsis: Moving to a new school and struggling to meet friends, Geraldine befriends a fellow outcast and learns to be comfortable with who she is.

Title: Giraffes Can’t Dance
Author: Andrae, Giles
Subject: Individuality
Synopsis: Gerald is too clumsy to dance with all the other animals, until he finds the right music.
Awards:
IRA Children’s Choice Award
IRA Teacher’s Choice Award

Title: The Day You Begin
Author: Woodson, Jacqueline
Subject: Individuality, friendship, and schools
Synopsis: How a new student feels like an outsider and learn everyone feels that way when the first start at a new school

Title: Hair Love
Author: Cherry, Matthew A.
Subject:
Father daughter relationship
Hairstyles
Synopsis: A little girl’s dad steps in to help her arrange her wild hair into styles that allow her to be her natural, beautiful self.

Title: Parker Looks Up
Author:
Curry, Parker
Curry, Jessica
Subject:
Role model
Inspiration
Synopsis: When Parker Curry came face-to-face with Amy Sherald's transcendent portrait of First Lady Michelle Obama ... She saw dynamic self-assurance. She saw truth and beauty. She saw a queen. But most importantly, Parker saw Her hopes. Her dreams, Her power. Her promise. Herself

Title: Everybody Cooks Rice
Author: Dooley, Norah
Subject: Culture practices
Synopsis: A child is sent to find a younger brother at dinnertime and is introduced to a variety of cultures through encountering the many different ways rice is prepared at the different households visited.
